content.text:
claude sdk costs 15x more than gemini. i'm using it anyway.

The numbers:
Gemini Flash: $0.00008/task
Claude Sonnet: $0.0012/task
OpenAI GPT-5: $0.0015/task

Google wins on price. Claude wins on clarity.

OpenAI's confusion:
â€¢ Swarm (Oct 2024): "Educational only, don't use in production"
â€¢ Agents SDK (Mar 2025): Production Swarm, still OpenAI-locked
â€¢ AgentKit (Oct 2025): Managed platform

Three products. No clear path.

Claude SDK:
â€¢ One answer (Sep 29, 2025)
â€¢ Self-hosted (you own the runtime)
â€¢ MCP open standard (200+ community servers)
â€¢ Production-ready from day 1

The strategic difference:

OpenAI launches feel reactive. Swarm deprecated for Agents SDK. Agents SDK shadowed by AgentKit. Throwing products at the wall.

Anthropic launches feed forward. Claude Code â†’ MCP â†’ Agent SDK â†’ Skills. Each builds on the last. Clear roadmap execution.

The ecosystem bet:

Every app will embed agents. Not as standalone products. As integrated features.

That requires self-hosting, customization, zero lock-in.

Claude SDK delivers.
AgentKit doesn't.

claude's 15x premium buys:
â€¢ real control (not managed dependency)
â€¢ open standards (mcp, not proprietary)
â€¢ ecosystem velocity (community, not vendor-only)

openai has three answers. anthropic has one. i'm paying the premium.

tweets:
openai shipped three agent runtimes in 12 months.

swarm: stateless client-side
agents sdk: managed orchestration
agentkit: visual platform

anthropic shipped one: self-hosted runtime with open protocol.

architectural divergence that determines who wins. ðŸ§µ

The agent runtime problem:

You need:
â€¢ State persistence across turns
â€¢ Tool execution coordination
â€¢ Memory management (short + long-term)
â€¢ Error boundaries and recovery
â€¢ Observability and tracing

Two approaches emerged. Only one scales.

Swarm (Oct 2024):

Architecture: Stateless client-side loop
State: None between runs
Tool calls: LLM-driven function calls
Handoffs: Via special functions

README literally says:
"Educational framework... not intended for production"

Why? No state persistence. No session management. No recovery.

Stateless client-side agents fail in production:

Scenario: Multi-turn support conversation
Turn 1: Agent gathers context
Turn 2: Network failure
Turn 3: Agent has no memory of Turn 1

Result: Start over. Every. Time.

Context window â‰  durable state management.

This is why Swarm is "educational only."

Agents SDK (Mar 2025):

Architecture: Production-ready with sessions
State: Automatic conversation history
Tool execution: Built-in agent loop
Tracing: Platform-integrated

Upgrade from Swarm:
âœ“ Session management
âœ“ State persistence
âœ“ Retry logic

Lock-in cost:
âœ— OpenAI-centric design
âœ— Provider abstraction missing

Agents SDK sessions solve state problem.

But introduce coupling:

Session storage: Where?
State serialization: How?
Multi-region: Sync?
Failover: Recovery path?

Managed platforms answer: "we handle it"

Cost: You're dependent on their infrastructure, their limits, their SLA.

AgentKit (Oct 2025):

Full platform architecture:
â€¢ Visual builder (DAG composition)
â€¢ Managed runtime (OpenAI hosts)
â€¢ Connector registry (tool catalog)
â€¢ Evals pipeline (trace grading)

Abstracts away:
Runtime deployment, scaling, monitoring, state

Abstracts away:
Control, customization, data residency

Managed platforms hit architectural ceiling:

Custom tool integration: Wait for vendor
Data compliance: Trust vendor infrastructure
Deployment regions: Limited to vendor's
Cost optimization: Model selection only
Tool execution: Black box

Fast to prototype.
Constrained in production.

Claude SDK (Sep 29, 2025):

Architecture: Self-hosted agent runtime
State: You manage (Redis, Postgres, S3)
Tools: MCP protocol (open standard)
Execution: In-process or serverless

Built on harness powering Claude Code.

No managed abstraction.
No platform lock-in.
Full architectural control.

MCP (Model Context Protocol):

Spec: JSON-RPC 2.0 message transport
Architecture: Client-server bidirectional
Primitives: Resources, Tools, Prompts, Sampling

State machine:
1. Initialize (capability negotiation)
2. Tool discovery (schema exchange)
3. Tool invocation (execution)
4. Result streaming

Open standard.

MCP vs AgentKit connectors:

MCP:
â€¢ Protocol spec public (JSON-RPC 2.0)
â€¢ Community builds tools (200+ servers)
â€¢ Import: npm install @modelcontextprotocol/server-xyz
â€¢ Runtime: In-process or stdio transport

AgentKit:
â€¢ Registry = curated by OpenAI
â€¢ Request access via platform
â€¢ Runtime: Managed only

Tool calling execution models:

Managed (AgentKit):
LLM â†’ Platform â†’ Tool â†’ Platform â†’ LLM
Latency: Network hops Ã— 2
Control: Zero (black box)

Self-hosted (Claude SDK):
LLM â†’ Your Runtime â†’ Tool â†’ Your Runtime â†’ LLM
Latency: In-process or controlled
Control: Full (you own execution)

State persistence architecture:

AgentKit:
Managed state store (OpenAI hosts)
Serialization: Handled
Multi-region: Unknown
Backup: Unknown

Claude SDK:
Bring your own state (Redis, RDS, S3)
Serialization: Your choice
Multi-region: Your topology
Backup: Your policy

Flexibility = complexity cost.

Deployment control:

Managed platforms:
Single region per account.
Vendor-defined AZs.
SLA = vendor's promise.
Data residency = vendor's infrastructure.

Self-hosted:
Multi-region by design.
Your AZs, your redundancy.
SLA = your architecture.
Data residency = your deployment.

Compliance isn't optional.

Observability architecture:

AgentKit:
Built-in trace grading.
Visual DAG execution.
Platform-integrated metrics.

Trade: Convenience vs custom instrumentation.

Claude SDK:
Bring your own observability.
OpenTelemetry, Datadog, custom.
Full trace ownership.

Trade: Setup cost vs flexibility.

Cost model differences:

AgentKit:
Token costs + managed platform overhead.
No self-hosting = no cost control beyond model selection.

Claude SDK:
Token costs only (self-hosted = no platform fee).
Caching: 90% savings (cache hits $0.30/MTok vs $3).
Batch API: 50% discount.

Control = optimization opportunity.

Community contribution models:

Proprietary (AgentKit):
Tools: Vendor curates
Updates: Vendor timeline
Extensions: Vendor approval

Open standard (MCP):
Tools: Community builds (200+ servers in 6 months)
Updates: npm publish
Extensions: Fork + PR

Network effects favor open.

The launch pattern tells the story:

OpenAI: Swarm (deprecated) â†’ Agents SDK â†’ AgentKit.
Reactive. Fragmented. Overlapping products.

Anthropic: Claude Code â†’ MCP â†’ Agent SDK â†’ Skills.
Feed-forward. Each launch builds on the last.

One company has a roadmap.
The other is throwing features at the wall.

why i'm betting on claude sdk:

â€¢ self-hosted deployment (compliance = mine)
â€¢ mcp open standard (community velocity)
â€¢ production-ready (no "educational only" BS)
â€¢ clear architectural progression

openai's playing product roulette.
anthropic's executing a strategy.

i'm paying the premium.

content.text:
OpenAI shipped three agent runtimes in 12 months. Anthropic shipped one.

The architectural divergence determines who wins.

**OpenAI's three products:**

â€¢ Swarm (Oct 2024): Stateless client-side loop. README says "educational framework... not intended for production." 20.6K GitHub stars, explicitly NOT for real apps.

â€¢ Agents SDK (Mar 2025): Production-ready upgrade of Swarm. But docs say "designed to work primarily with OpenAI's models." Open source code â‰  open ecosystem. Still locked to OpenAI infrastructure.

â€¢ AgentKit (Oct 2025): Managed platform. Visual builder, connector registry, OpenAI hosts your runtime. Convenient until you need custom tools, data residency, or compliance controls.

Three products in 12 months. No clear path.

**Anthropic's one answer:**

Claude SDK (Sep 29, 2025):
âœ“ Self-hosted agent runtime (you control deployment)
âœ“ MCP protocol (JSON-RPC 2.0 open standard)
âœ“ 200+ community MCP servers (vs proprietary registry)
âœ“ Production-ready from day 1 (no educational disclaimers)

Built on the same harness that powers Claude Code.

**The technical difference:**

State management:
â€¢ AgentKit: Managed state (unknown serialization, backup, topology)
â€¢ Claude SDK: Your infrastructure (Redis, RDS, S3 - your choice)

Tool execution:
â€¢ AgentKit: Network hops Ã— 2 (200-800ms latency, black box)
â€¢ Claude SDK: In-process (10-50ms, full control)

Deployment:
â€¢ AgentKit: OpenAI regions only
â€¢ Claude SDK: AWS, GCP, on-prem, anywhere (GDPR, HIPAA, SOC2 = your architecture)

**The strategic pattern:**

OpenAI: Swarm (deprecated) â†’ Agents SDK â†’ AgentKit
Pattern: Reactive. Fragmented. Overlapping products.

Anthropic: Claude Code â†’ MCP â†’ Agent SDK â†’ Skills
Pattern: Feed-forward. Each launch builds on the last.

One company has a roadmap. The other is experimenting in public.

**The ecosystem bet:**

Every application will embed agents. Not as standalone products, but as integrated features.

That requires self-hosting, customization, and zero platform lock-in.

MCP open standard: Build tools once, works everywhere. 200+ community servers in 6 months. Community velocity > vendor gatekeeping.

AgentKit's proprietary registry: Curated by OpenAI. Request new connectors. Wait for approval.

**Why I'm betting on Claude SDK:**

Not because it's cheaper (it's not).
Not because it's easier (AgentKit's visual builder wins on speed).

Because architecture matters more than price in the long game.

Standards win. Proprietary systems fragment.
Self-hosted scales. Managed platforms hit ceilings.
Community velocity > vendor control.

I'm paying the premium.

---

Follow me for technical deep-dives on AI infrastructure, agent architectures, and platform engineering.

What's your agent platform choice? And what architectural factors matter most to your decision?

#AIAgents #TechnicalArchitecture #CloudInfrastructure #EngineeringLeadership #OpenSource
